name: spectrometer
title: Gamma Ray and Neutron Spectrometer
description: This tool helps figure out what the asteroid is made of by detecting gamma rays and neutrons. Cosmic rays hit the asteroid, and this instrument measures the energy that bounces back.

name: antenna
title: X-Band High Gain Antenna
description: This dish-shaped antenna points at Earth and sends pictures and data back at high-speeds using X-band radio waves, across the vastness of space.

name: imager
title: Multispectral Imager
description: These cameras take high quality pictures of the asteroid. They use filters to tell the difference between metal and rock, helping scientists understand its shape, makeup, and surface.

name: communication
title: Deep Space Optical Communication
description: This complex new laser system sends messages using light instead of traditional radio waves. It’s faster and can send more information across space.

name: detection
title: Magnetometer
description: This instrument looks for magnetic clues around the asteroid. It has two sensitive sensors on a long boom to measure the asteroid’s magnetic field which will uncover its history.

name: propulsion
title: SPT-140 Engines
description: Psyche uses unique thrusters that run on electricity from its solar panels. They gently push the spacecraft through space by shooting out charged atoms, guiding it through its long mission.

name: arrays
title: Solar Arrays
description: Psyche uses large X-shaped solar panel arrays that capture sunlight to power all its instruments and systems. Even far from the Sun, these panels provide enough energy for the spacecraft’s needs.
